Park City Hiking Trails

400+ Miles of Scenic Trails Through Mountains, Meadows & Forests

Popular Hiking Trails

From leisurely strolls to challenging summit hikes, Park City offers trails for every ability

Armstrong Trail

Difficulty: Easy | Distance: 4 miles round trip

  • Perfect beginner trail with gradual incline
  • Stunning views of Park City and Deer Valley
  • Wildflowers in summer, golden aspens in fall
  • Dog-friendly on even days
  • Trailhead: Top of Main Street

Bloods Lake

Difficulty: Moderate | Distance: 2.6 miles round trip

  • Beautiful alpine lake destination
  • 550 feet elevation gain
  • Great for families with kids
  • Swimming allowed in summer
  • Trailhead: Guardsman Pass Road

Rob's Trail

Difficulty: Moderate | Distance: 4.7 miles round trip

  • Popular trail with valley views
  • Connects to extensive trail network
  • Mountain bikers on odd days only
  • Great workout with steady climb
  • Trailhead: Round Valley

Silver Lake Trail

Difficulty: Easy | Distance: 0.8 mile loop

  • Boardwalk trail around scenic lake
  • Wheelchair accessible
  • Excellent wildlife viewing
  • Perfect for all ages
  • Location: Deer Valley Resort

PC Hill

Difficulty: Hard | Distance: 7 miles round trip

  • Challenging climb to 360Â° views
  • 1,700 feet elevation gain
  • Summit at 9,000 feet
  • Best at sunrise or sunset
  • Trailhead: Creekside Park

Jenni's Trail

Difficulty: Moderate | Distance: 3 miles loop

  • Beautiful aspen groves
  • Multiple route options
  • Less crowded alternative
  • Great for trail running
  • Access: Jeremy Ranch

Trail Systems & Areas

Round Valley

Park City's most popular trail network

  • 30+ miles of trails
  • All skill levels
  • Dog-friendly areas
  • Free parking
  • Open year-round

Mid Mountain Trail

Epic 20-mile trail connecting both resorts

  • Follows 8,000-foot contour
  • Moderate difficulty
  • Can bike or hike
  • Multiple access points
  • Incredible views

Glenwild

Newer trail system with diverse terrain

  • 17 miles of trails
  • Less crowded
  • Technical options
  • Great fall colors
  • Connects to other systems

Seasonal Hiking Guide

Spring (April-May)

  • Lower elevation trails open first
  • Muddy conditions common
  • Wildflower season begins
  • Variable weather - layer up
  • Less crowded trails

Best trails: Armstrong, Round Valley, Rail Trail

Summer (June-August)

  • All trails typically open
  • Wildflowers at peak
  • Early morning best
  • Afternoon thunderstorms
  • Busiest season

Best trails: Bloods Lake, Silver Lake, PC Hill

Fall (September-October)

  • Spectacular aspen colors
  • Cooler temperatures
  • Less crowded
  • Stable weather
  • Peak viewing: late Sept

Best trails: Jenni's, Mid Mountain, Armstrong

Trail Etiquette & Safety

Trail Rules

  • Yield to uphill hikers
  • Mountain bikers yield to hikers
  • Everyone yields to horses
  • Stay on designated trails
  • Pack out all trash
  • Control your dog
  • Respect private property

Safety Tips

  • Start early to avoid crowds/heat
  • Bring 2L+ water per person
  • Watch for altitude effects
  • Tell someone your plans
  • Download offline maps
  • Carry bear spray (rare but wise)
  • Check weather before going

What to Bring

  • Plenty of water
  • Snacks/lunch
  • Sun protection
  • First aid kit
  • Map/GPS device
  • Layers for weather
  • Emergency whistle

Family-Friendly Hikes

McPolin Farm Nature Trail

Perfect for: Young kids, strollers

  • 0.5 mile flat loop
  • Historic barn photo op
  • Interpretive signs
  • Picnic areas
  • Free parking

Swaner Preserve

Perfect for: Nature lovers, bird watching

  • 1.2 mile boardwalk
  • Wetland ecosystem
  • Wildlife viewing
  • Educational center
  • All abilities

Trailside Park Loop

Perfect for: Quick exercise, dogs

  • 2.5 mile paved path
  • Playground stops
  • Creek access
  • Bike friendly
  • Year-round use

Advanced Hiking Adventures

Jupiter Peak

Summit elevation: 10,050 feet

  • 6 miles, 2,000 ft gain
  • Panoramic summit views
  • Access via ski resort
  • Rocky, exposed terrain
  • Start very early

Desolation Lake

Alpine lake: 9,240 feet

  • 7.4 miles round trip
  • Through Big Cottonwood
  • Multiple lake options
  • Wildflower meadows
  • Less crowded gem

Clayton Peak

Summit elevation: 10,721 feet

  • 4.4 miles, 1,366 ft gain
  • 360-degree views
  • Above treeline hiking
  • Weather dependent
  • July-September best

Trail Resources

Trail Maps & Apps

  • AllTrails: User reviews & GPS
  • Trailforks: Detailed topo maps
  • Basin Rec: Official trail info
  • MTB Project: Bike-specific
  • Download offline maps!

Guided Hikes

  • White Pine Touring: Nature walks
  • All Seasons Adventures: Custom trips
  • Park City Yoga: Hike & yoga combos
  • Utah Outdoor: Photography hikes
  • Rates: $75-150 per person

Trail Conditions

  • Check Basin Recreation website
  • Mountain Trails Foundation updates
  • Local Facebook groups
  • Resort trail reports
  • Weather: NOAA.gov
